subject: RE: [junit] Digest Number 109
msgSnippet: If you use a suite() method in your TestCase, JUnit will take just the tests you add there.  You can write the test ahead of time and then add the test to the
messageBody:
RE: [junit] Digest Number 109
If you use a suite() method in your TestCase, JUnit will take just the tests you add there.  You can write the test ahead of time and then add the test to the TestCase's suite method when the production code is ready to be tested.
 
I like the idea--it would be nice to see output something like:
 
    [junit] Running com.peregrine.gis.TestMultipleServerStarter
    [junit] Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Todo: 2, Errors: 0, Time elapsed: 8.181 sec
    [junit]     todoSomeNewThing
    [junit]     todoSomeOtherNewThing
    [junit] Running com.peregrine.gis.TestThreadInfo
    [junit] Tests run: 3, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Time elapsed: 4.547 sec
    [junit] Running com.peregrine.gis.TestUtil
    [junit] Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Time elapsed: 0.01 sec
 
That way you would be reminded of the tests you have yet to implement.
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Todd Jonker [mailto:tjonker@...]
Sent: Thursday, March 15, 2001 9:55 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Digest Number 109

I think this is a terrific idea.  I've been wanting to find a way to support the notion of "expected failures" to account for test-first unit testing, and for future-work functional tests.  I was going to try to use an external file listing the tests that can be expected to fail, and then writing a TestListener or somesuch that checks the actual failures against the list.  This is clearly a much more elegant design.  (And it obeys OAOO!)

My only suggestion would be to a command line option (well, actually, an Ant taskdef attribute :-) to specify whether or not the todos should be run.  If they are run, report on the todos that (perhaps unexpectedly) passed, but don't Go Red if any of them fail.

This would be extremely useful in my project, where we are using JUnit + HttpUnit to build our suite of functional test.  Currently we can't "work ahead" writing the functional tests since the unimplemented ones will break the build!  I'd like to simply ignore the todos when testing the

ContinuousIntegration build, but keep them enabled in the development environment so the coders know what still needs to be done.

Thanks for the excellent idea!

.T.

Todd V. Jonker
Sr. Technical Associate
ZEFER Pittsburgh


> Date: Mon, 12 Mar 2001 21:59:01 -0000
> From: jcarpenter@...
> Subject: todo tests in JUnit (think Perl)

> We are finding that there are times when it may be desirable to check
> into source control code that is not fully implemented.  The tests
> may be defined, but the corresponding class implementation may not be
> complete.
>
> Perl's standard framework has the concept of a todo test.  A simple
> enough way to notate such a test in JUnit would be to name a method
> within a test todoBlah, rather than testBlah.  To safely go down this
> road, it is desirable to extend JUnit to report on what todo tests
> are in the code base in addition to the normal tests.  I am
> considering writting such an extension and contributing it back to
> the JUnit project.  Unfortuantely, I don't know where in the JUnit
> code base to start.
